results.title: [Melbourne]
results.brief_description: An amateur film shot in Melbourne around 1935 which includes: footage of school children and gardeners in the Treasury and Fitzroy Gardens; a glimpse of traffic and a No. 13 tram in the city; construction work at the Shrine of Rememberance.

results.title: Nimmo St
results.brief_description: This film is a short drama with a musical soundtrack and no dialogue set around Nimmo Street in Middle Park, Melbourne. A young man meets a woman arriving on a ‘Red Rattler’ train and walks her home. On the way, they are accosted by two thugs but manage to avoid conflict. When the young woman reaches her home and doesn’t invite the man in, he leaves and takes out his frustration on the thugs when he encounters them again in the street. A simple, beautifully shot, low budget film capturing Melbourne’s inner suburban street life.

results.title: Thomson of Arnhem Land
results.creator_credit: Andrea Lang, Michael Cummins, John Moore, Michael McMahon, John Moore Productions and Film Australia
results.brief_description: In the 1930s tensions between the government and the indigenous people of Australia’s North were on a knife-edge. Donald Thomson, an anthropologist, volunteered to go to Arnhem Land to make peace. For over two years, he lived with the Aboriginal people, forging strong bonds, learning and recording their way of life. His report to the government outlined a vision of land rights and other measures to protect a unique yet fragile culture. It was ignored. Ostracised by politicians and fellow academics, Thomson never gave up the struggle for Aboriginal rights. Now, his extraordinary photographs, field notes and artefacts are considered one of the most significant ethnographic collections in the world. Thomson’s collection is held at the Museum of Victoria in Melbourne. Narrated by Anni Finsterer. Music by David Bridie.

results.title: A Place Called Mooroopna
results.creator_credit: John Richardson, Adrian Boddington and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description: Documents a young Scottish migrant’s arrival to Melbourne and his subsequent journey with his new found Aussie mate around Australia. They visit Portsea and travel through various country areas of Victoria finally stopping at Mooroopna when their car breaks down. The Scotsman gets a job at Mooroopna in the local Ardmona Fruit Cannery for the season. The film shows the making of cans and the processing and canning of the peach and pear crops.

results.title: Bush and beach around Melbourne
results.brief_description:
This film is made up of various scenes of coastal and bush areas in and around Victoria: life saving display at St. Kilda; some views around the beaches to Portsea; bathers and motor boating across the bay to Queenscliff; into the nearest ranges, fields of daffodils around Healesville, Marysville and Warburton districts; gun-dogs in action; fly-fishing; the Dandenong ranges.
No credits available.

results.title: The Melbourne Wedding Belle
results.creator_credit: Colin Dean, Maslyn Williams, Australian National Film Board and Australia. Dept. of the Interior. Film Division
results.brief_description: Set to a poetic musical dialogue, this film shows the beauty of Melbourne and gardens as the bride, groom etc gather for a wedding at St John’s Church in Toorak (Melbourne).

results.title: Morning paper
results.creator_credit: Darrel Catling, Donald Carter, H. Bruce Woolfe and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: The story of a newspaper during wartime. Shows how the news is gathered and prepared for the press in spite of the threat of bombs. Describes the composition and checking of the pages, the creation of curved steroes to fit the rotary presses and various other tasks that must be completed before the paper can be put to bed.

results.title: A Place to live
results.creator_credit: Stuart Glover, Frank Bagnall, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Film Academy
results.brief_description: Story of immigration and discussion of how newcomers look for houses, units or commission housing on offer in the city. Immigration officers help migrants get loans and settle in ‘suburbia’, the ideal for many migrants.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stuart Glover, Frank Bagnall, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Film Academy

results.title: Walkabout
results.creator_credit: Nicolas Roeg, Si Litvinoff and Max L. Raab - Si Litvinoff Films
results.brief_description: Nicolas Roeg’s lyrical tale about a sister and her young brother left stranded in the Australian outback having survived their father’s attempt to destroy the family. They’re rescued by a young Aboriginal man (David Gulpilil) who has journeyed into the vast desert on his walkabout - a tribal initiation into manhood.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Nicolas Roeg, Si Litvinoff and Max L. Raab - Si Litvinoff Films
results.description: Nicolas Roeg’s lyrical tale about a sister (Jenny Agutter) and her young brother (Lucien John) left stranded in the Australian outback having survived their father’s attempt to destroy the family. They are rescued by a young Aboriginal man (David Gulpilil) who has journeyed into the vast desert on his walkabout - a tribal initiation into manhood. During their journey Gulpilil courts the young woman, though in her incomprehension she rejects his advances. The vision of paradise lost presented with an often surreal intensity is that of a European outsider, who sees white history as invasive and deeply destructive. Also stars John Meillon, Robert McDara, Pete Carver, John Illingsworth, Hilary Bamberger, Barry Donnelly, Noelene Brown and Carlo Machini. Screenplay by Edward Bond, based on the novel by James Vance Marshall. Edited by Antony Gibbs and Alan Pattillo. Music composed and conducted by John Barry.

results.title: Sunbury
results.creator_credit: John Dixon and Cambridge Film Production
results.brief_description: The Sunbury Music Festival, held each Australia Day between 1972 and 1975 holds fond memories for the 35,000 plus people who attended. This video shows highlights of the first festival in 1972 and captures the excitement of a festival which showcased Australian Rock music and provides a document of Australian society in the seventies.
